linkTarget.anchoringText: Large supplies of heavy and extra-heavy crude oils will be needed in Venezuela for the next coming years to replace the production decline of medium and light crude oils. Enhanced-Oil-Recovery (EOR, Figure 1) and upgrading techniques are required; being imperative to the development of technical and economic feasibility studies of the underlying development projects (Layrisse, I. et al. 1999), knowing that the risk and concerns on heavy and extra-heavy oil production remains: oil prices, environmental regulations, operating costs, etc.

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Life of an oil field with an EOR program implementation (Henthorne, L. et al. 2011 ).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Life of an oil field with an EOR program implementation (Henthorne, L. et al. 2011 ).

linkTarget.bib:
Henthorne et al., 2011
L. Henthorne ; M. Hartman and A. Hayden ; 2011. Improving Chemical EOR Economics by Optimizing Water Quality. SPE 144397 presented at the SPE Enhanced Oil Recovery Conference held in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia , 19–21 July.

linkTarget.anchoringText: In the FPO, only 40–65% (depending on the site) of the oil-bearing formations are suitable for thermal methods (including both the development of horizontal wells; and targeting thick reservoirs); other beds are too thin, have too low kh/p values, and have unfavorable kv/kh ratios because of clay laminations (Dusseault et al. 2001). Based on the work of Zan Cheng (2010), the steam flooding is not recommended for thin extra-heavy oil bed of the FPO with horizontal and multilateral wells. Typical complex well configurations in one of the block of the FPO are reported by Cuadros, G. et al. 2015 (Figure 2).

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Typical well cluster configuration in some FPO’s reservoirs (Cuadros, G. et al. 2015 ).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Typical well cluster configuration in some FPO’s reservoirs (Cuadros, G. et al. 2015 ).

linkTarget.bib:
Cuadros et al., 2015
G. Cuadros ; E. H. Chamat ; N. Villarroel ; J. Scrofina ; E. Cermeno and O. Rodriguez ; 2015. Improving Horizontal Well Placement in the Orinoco Oil Belt with the Use of Bed Boundary Mapping Technologies. Paper SPE-174476-MS presented at the SPE Canada Heavy Oil Technical Conference held in Calgary, Alberta, Canada , 9–11 June.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The main lithologic rock properties of the thin-bedded reservoir of this research work are sands, silts, shales and coals, bed thickness between 20 and 40 ft. (Figure 3). Other reservoir properties of this reservoir are listed below

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Sand packages in vertical wells vary from thick massive sands to thinly laminated sands. This variability is dictated by the well’s location in regards to the areal distribution of the depositional facies ( Kooper, R. et al. 2001 ).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Sand packages in vertical wells vary from thick massive sands to thinly laminated sands. This variability is dictated by the well’s location in regards to the areal distribution of the depositional facies ( Kooper, R. et al. 2001 ).

linkTarget.bib:
Kooper et al., 2001
R. Kooper ; J. Kupecz ; C. Curtis ; T. Cole ; D. Dorn-Lopez ; J. Copley ; A. Munoz ; V. Caicedo ; 2001. Reservoir Characterization of the Orinoco Oil Belt: Miocene Oficina Formation, Zuata Field, Eastern Venezuelan Basin. Paper SPE 69697 presented at the 2001 SPE International Operations and Heavy Oil Symposium held in Porlamar, Margarita Island, Venezuela , 12–14 March.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The oil was heated to 40°C, homogenized and submitted to decantation before determining its water content. This means that the 6 wt-% water measured by Karl Fischer method corresponds to a rather stable water in oil emulsion. This hypothesis is supported by microscopy (Figure 4) as relatively small water droplets are observed (typical size 1–5 μm). No further efforts were made to remove the stable water droplets in this study.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Microscope picture showing water droplets in the crude oil sample.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Microscope picture showing water droplets in the crude oil sample.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The oil viscosity was 4500 cP at the reference case reservoir temperature of 50°C (Figure 5) and its API gravity 9°. This means that the oil density was close to that of water at room temperature. For these reasons, adapted procedures needed to be implemented for handling the oil and achieving good separation of oil and water phases during the surfactant formulation design process or the analysis of the effluents of the coreflood tests.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Picture of the dead crude oil illustrating its very high viscosity.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Picture of the dead crude oil illustrating its very high viscosity.

linkTarget.anchoringText: As this reservoir rock is unconsolidated, a specific procedure was applied to prepare the plug (Figure 6): the core was CT-scanned to select a fairly homogenous zone and the plug was drilled using a puncher. Due to the unconsolidated state of the reservoir rock, the depressurization of the core led to the formation of multiple fissures (see the CT-scan radiography): this means that the actual structure of the reservoir rock was likely not reproduced in the coreflood test and that notions of vertical and horizontal permeabilities are not relevant in this case.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Reservoir rock sample. CT-scan radiography (the red circles indicates the zone selected for the plug), picture illustrating the methodology and tools used to take the plug (use of a puncher and drilling along the axis of the core, see text), and enlarged image from microscopy of the received reservoir rock material.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Reservoir rock sample. CT-scan radiography (the red circles indicates the zone selected for the plug), picture illustrating the methodology and tools used to take the plug (use of a puncher and drilling along the axis of the core, see text), and enlarged image from microscopy of the received reservoir rock material.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Besides, the total surfactant concentration was incremented from 1 to 10 g/L, in order to identify any concentration effect on the phase diagram. For all experiments, the polymer concentration remained constant and set to 2.5 g/L (real polymer concentration determined by dosage of carbon and nitrogen with a TOC-V CSN analyzer from Shimadzu). Results are disclosed in Figure 7.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Solubility (a) and phase behavior (b) screening for the surfactant formulation F#1 at the contact with this Venezuelan extra-heavy oil as a function of brine salinity and total surfactant concentration. Temperature was set at 50°C for these scans; digits reported above the test tubes correspond to brine salinity (TDS, g/L); and digits reported to the left of the tubes correspond to the total surfactant concentration (g/L). Formulation solubility is excellent for all the range of salinity and surfactant concentration tested. Low interfacial tensions were noticed for reservoir brine (6.4 g/L TDS) at all surfactant concentrations.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Solubility (a) and phase behavior (b) screening for the surfactant formulation F#1 at the contact with this Venezuelan extra-heavy oil as a function of brine salinity and total surfactant concentration. Temperature was set at 50°C for these scans; digits reported above the test tubes correspond to brine salinity (TDS, g/L); and digits reported to the left of the tubes correspond to the total surfactant concentration (g/L). Formulation solubility is excellent for all the range of salinity and surfactant concentration tested. Low interfacial tensions were noticed for reservoir brine (6.4 g/L TDS) at all surfactant concentrations.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Viscosimetry Flow curves obtained for the surfactant, the polymer alone and the SP formulation are presented on Figure 8. The relative viscosities presented were calculated with a measured brine viscosity of 0.51 cP at 50°C. It can be seen that the surfactant alone has a relative viscosity close to 1, namely the same viscosity as the brine, and that no surfactant-polymer interaction affects the viscosity of the SP formulation as its viscosity is almost the same as that of the polymer alone.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Flow curves (relative viscosity versus shear rate) determined for the polymer alone, the surfactant alone and the surfactant-polymer mixture. Temperature: 50°C; brine viscosity: 0.51 cP.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Flow curves (relative viscosity versus shear rate) determined for the polymer alone, the surfactant alone and the surfactant-polymer mixture. Temperature: 50°C; brine viscosity: 0.51 cP.

linkTarget.anchoringText: CT-scan analysis (Exp. 1–3: Bentheimer sandstone) Oil saturation profiles obtained by CT-scan at the end of each step are presented in Figure 9,Figure 10 and Figure 11 respectively for Exp. 1, Exp. 2 and Exp. 3. The average oil saturations and the corresponding cumulative ΔOOIP (variation with respect to the Original Oil In Place) are presented in Table 3. Results show that the oil saturation profiles are fairly flat in a first approximation and that the average saturations determined are meaningful.

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Oil saturation profiles determined by CT-scan after various steps of Exp. 1: Waterflood (after low and high flow rate), Polymer flood and Surfactant-Polymer flood.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Oil saturation profiles determined by CT-scan after various steps of Exp. 1: Waterflood (after low and high flow rate), Polymer flood and Surfactant-Polymer flood.

Results show that the oil saturation profiles are fairly flat in a first approximation and that the average saturations determined are meaningful.

The average oil saturations and the corresponding cumulative ΔOOIP (variation with respect to the Original Oil In Place) are presented in Table 3. linkTarget.anchoringText: Cumulative oil production data are presented in Figure 12 over 2 PVI respectively for the secondary waterflood (low flow rate sequence) of Exp. 1, surfactant flood of Exp. 2 and SP flood of Exp. 3. Figure 13 reports for the same set of results but over a larger PVI scale, together with the results of the tertiary polymer injection step in Exp. 2. Pressure drop (AP) obtained during the first steps are presented on Figure 14.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Graphical interpretation (Exp. 1–3: Bentheimer sandstone) Figure 15 presents a qualitative graphical interpretation that summarizes the comments and interpretations provided in the above text. This shows that the relative contributions of sweep and mobilization of residual oil are consistent for all experiments.

image-wrap.label: Figure 15
image-wrap.caption: Qualitative graphical interpretation of the results of the injection scenarios investigated.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Qualitative graphical interpretation of the results of the injection scenarios investigated.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Oil production (Exp. 4: reservoir rock) Cumulative oil production (as %OOIP produced versus PVI) obtained during the secondary SP injection of Exp. 4 (reservoir rock) is presented in Figure 16, together with that of Exp. 3 (the corresponding experiment on Bentheimer sandstone). From this plot and also from the results gathered in Table 3, it clearly appears that the final oil recovery is very good in both cases, with final oil recovery above 90% of the OOIP.

image-wrap.label: Figure 16
image-wrap.caption: Cumulative oil production data (as % OOIP) vs. PVI determined during injection at low flow rate in Exp. 3 (Surfactant-Polymer flood in Bentheimer sandstone) and in Exp. 4 (Surfactant-Polymer flood in reservoir rock).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Cumulative oil production data (as % OOIP) vs. PVI determined during injection at low flow rate in Exp. 3 (Surfactant-Polymer flood in Bentheimer sandstone) and in Exp. 4 (Surfactant-Polymer flood in reservoir rock).

linkTarget.anchoringText: History matching of waterflood (Exp. 1, low flow-rate sequence) and surfactant flood (Exp.2) As shown in Figure 17,Figure 18,Figure 19 and Figure 20, satisfactory agreements were found for oil production and pressure drop for both Exp. 1 and Exp. 2.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The corresponding relative permeability curves are plotted in Figure 21. It should be emphasized that the relative permeabilities were evaluated without considering, neither the effect of surfactant adsorption nor the control of the end-points with a capillary desaturation curve. According to the strategy selected in this work, all phenomena that occur at pore scale were captured macroscopically by the effective permeability coefficients.

image-wrap.label: Figure 21
image-wrap.caption: Relative permeabilities for water flooding in Exp. 1 (blue curves) and surfactant flooding in Exp. 2 (red curves). The relative permeabilities were derived by history matching the experimental data. (a) and (b): relative permeabilities of water and oil respectively in linear scale; (c): relative permeability for both water and secondary surfactant flooding in log scale.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Relative permeabilities for water flooding in Exp. 1 (blue curves) and surfactant flooding in Exp. 2 (red curves). The relative permeabilities were derived by history matching the experimental data. (a) and (b): relative permeabilities of water and oil respectively in linear scale; (c): relative permeability for both water and secondary surfactant flooding in log scale.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: relative permeability for both water and secondary surfactant flooding in log scale

linkTarget.anchoringText: This explains why high residual oil saturation and low water relative permeability are found. The addition of surfactant to the injected water phase, in Exp. 2, leads to a reduction of the mobility of the water phase (above Sw ~ 0.35) and an increase of the mobility of the oil phase. Consequently, as shown in Figure 22, mobility ratio (mobility of the water phase over mobility of the oil phase), is clearly lower above Sw ~ 0.30 in presence of surfactant than without.

image-wrap.label: Figure 22
image-wrap.caption: Mobility ratio vs. water saturation. Water flooding in Exp. 1 (blue curves) and surfactant flooding in Exp. 2 (red curves).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Mobility ratio vs. water saturation. Water flooding in Exp. 1 (blue curves) and surfactant flooding in Exp. 2 (red curves).
